title: Launching and supporting Black-owned businesses | Mandy Bowman | TEDxDover
description:
We've read stats showing that Blacks have a buying power of $1.2 Trillion dollars and that Black women are starting businesses at a faster rate than any other group, but is this enough to change the economic inequalities that plague Black neighborhoods? Mandy Bowman discusses how it's time to focus on creating and supporting Black businesses to build long term/generational wealth.

Mandy Bowman is the Founder of Official Black Wall Street and the Social Media Manager at Essence Magazine. With a deep-rooted passion for all things social media, entrepreneurship, and Black culture, Mandy has worked tirelessly to empower and support Black entrepreneurs through her digital platform and Black business directory, Official Black Wall Street. When she isn't working to fuel Black businesses through the Official Black Wall Street platform, she is volunteering as a mentor to inner city students and creating social strategies.

This talk was given at a TEDx event using the TED conference format but independently organized by a local community. Learn more at http://ted.com/tedx

title: Closing the Wealth Gap: Felecia Hatcher Talks Black Ambition's Entrepreneurial Support
description:
In this episode of EYL, hosts Troy Millings and Rashad Bilal are joined by the dynamic Felecia Hatcher, CEO of Black Ambition. Felecia dives deep into the transformative work Black Ambition is doing to support Black entrepreneurs by providing not just mentorship but the right kind of mentorship that opens doors and creates tangible opportunities for growth.

Troy kicks off the discussion by highlighting the phrase ‚Äúdon‚Äôt build in the dark‚Äù and emphasizes the value of mentorship in a startup‚Äôs journey. Felecia elaborates on how Black Ambition differentiates itself by ensuring mentors don't just advise but actively support entrepreneurs through their networks. She stresses the disservice caused by mentors who offer feedback but won't leverage their contacts for the mentees who need them. The goal, as she puts it, is to have mentors who are willing to put you on and get out of the way, allowing entrepreneurs to flourish with the right resources at their disposal.

The conversation then delves into how Black Ambition sets itself apart. Felecia shares that Black Ambition boasts a network of 50 mentors who have opened doors to giant retailers like HSN, Target, and Walmart. This is a direct reflection of the program‚Äôs mission to close the wealth gap through speed and efficiency, understanding that time is a commodity that Black entrepreneurs simply can‚Äôt afford to waste.

The dialogue takes an inspiring turn as Troy brings up the collaboration between Jay-Z and Pharrell, part of the rollout for Black Ambition. Felecia gives us an insight into how Pharrell's creativity and entrepreneurial spirit gave birth to the initiative. She shares a heartwarming account of Pharrell's journey from Virginia to becoming a mogul with a legacy that now supports 101 entrepreneurs through Black Ambition.

Rashad probes further, asking Felecia how she connected with Pharrell and how involved he is with Black Ambition. Felecia candidly shares her experiences, describing her first encounters with Pharrell and how he remains hands-on despite his busy schedule in Paris and his role at Louis Vuitton. One standout anecdote recalls a feminine hygiene company, Femly, which struggled for two years to get into Marriott hotels. Pharrell, leveraging his contacts, made two phone calls and got them an opportunity within those two locations, a testament to the impactful mentorship Black Ambition promises.

Felecia also talks about the innovative learning labs created for Black Ambition entrepreneurs, offering unprecedented access to established corporate giants like LVMH and Chanel. This access includes premium insights into supply chain logistics, strategic planning from top-tier professionals, and mentorship from industry leaders, facilitated by the immense influence of Pharrell.

The discussion underscores an essential ethos: meaningful mentorship goes beyond advice; it requires action and advocacy. For Felecia, the litmus test for effective allies is simple ‚Äì if someone can make a vital connection for themselves, they should be willing to do it for Black entrepreneurs as well.

This episode of EYL with Felecia Hatcher is a must-watch for anyone passionate about entrepreneurship, mentorship, and closing the racial wealth gap. Be inspired by stories of real impact and learn how Black Ambition is paving the way for a new generation of successful Black entrepreneurs.

title: Steven S. Rogers - Successful Black Entrepreneurs
description:
Steven Rogers retired from Harvard Business School (HBS) in 2019 where he was the ‚ÄúMBA Class of 1957 Senior Lecturer‚Äù in General Management. 
He taught Entrepreneurial Finance and a new course that he created, titled ‚ÄúBlack Business Leaders and Entrepreneurship.‚Äù

A 1985 graduate of the school, Professor Rogers holds a Bachelor of Arts degree from Williams College. Prior to HBS, Professor Rogers taught in the MBA and PhD programs at the Kellogg School of Management, Northwestern University. He received the Outstanding Professor Award for the Executive MBA Program 26 times and daytime program twice. Both are records.

In 2023, he purchased a church that sits on land taken from Black families in 1929.

In 2022, he published his third book, Successful Black Entrepreneurs, and in 2021, he published, A Letter to my White Friends and Colleagues: What You Can Do Now to Help the Black Community. In 2020, he published the 4th edition of, Entrepreneurial Finance: Finance and Business Strategies for the Serious Entrepreneur. He has also authored 30 HBS case studies, most of which have Black protagonists. He has published more case studies with Black protagonists than anyone in the country. 

In 2019, he toured 10 HBCUs where he taught a workshop, Finance for Black Entrepreneurs. 

In 2017, he received the ‚ÄúBlack Brilliance in Service‚Äù award from Harvard Law School‚Äôs Black Law Students Association, and in that same year, Poets & Quants Magazine selected him as one of ‚ÄúOur Favorite MBA Professors of 2017."

He has been named one of the top 150 influential people in America by¬†Ebony Magazine, Rogers is the author of¬†The Entrepreneur's Guide to Finance and Business¬†and multiple Harvard Business School case studies and podcasts focused on Black business and financial issues.

He has completed five Triathlons and is part owner of the Chicago Sky, the 2021 WNBA Champions. 

Rogers has two daughters, Akilah and Ariel.

title: Empowering Entrepreneurs: Black Ambition‚Äôs Funding and Mentorship Strategies
description:
Welcome to another inspiring episode of EYL, where we shine a spotlight on some of the most impactful and innovative leaders in various industries. In this episode, our host, Rashad Bilal, dives deep into a conversation with Felecia Hatcher, a dynamic leader and the driving force behind Black Ambition.

### About Black Ambition:
Black Ambition is a non-profit organization dedicated to funding and supporting Black and Latinx entrepreneurs. Founded four years ago, the organization offers a unique platform that combines financial investment, mentorship, and holistic wellness support to empower entrepreneurs to achieve their dreams.

### Key Discussion Points:
1. **Equity Investment:** Felecia discusses how Black Ambition invests in startups through a streamlined process, taking a consistent equity stake across the board. Investments are facilitated through a safe agreement, offering an 80% discount, ensuring that the maximum benefit goes back into the entrepreneurial ecosystem.

2. **Mentorship and Networking:** One of the standout features of Black Ambition is its extensive mentorship program. Entrepreneurs receive guidance from industry-specific mentors who provide invaluable insights and expertise. The organization also leverages a vast network of wealthy individuals and corporations to help startups secure additional funding.

3. **Financial Support:** Black Ambition operates as a 501(c)(3) nonprofit, primarily funded by foundations and major corporate partners like LVMH, Adidas, Lennar Foundation, and Comcast NBCUniversal. This robust support structure enables the organization to inject capital into promising ventures and drive systemic change.

4. **Holistic Approach to Entrepreneurship:** Felecia highlights the organization's comprehensive approach, which includes access to therapy and mental health support. Entrepreneurs benefit from group wellness sessions and one-on-one counseling, helping them navigate the emotional and psychological challenges of running a business.

5. **Challenges and Successes:** The conversation delves into the highs and lows of the entrepreneurial journey, emphasizing the importance of resilience and mental fortitude. Felecia shares personal anecdotes and lessons learned, providing a blueprint for aspiring entrepreneurs to follow.

### Notable Quotes:
- **On Mentorship and Networking:** "We do it through a safe agreement. It's an 80% discount that we do. So it's a very small amount that comes back into Black Ambition so that we can fund more entrepreneurs." - Felecia Hatcher
- **On Financial Support:** "Most of our funding comes from foundations and major corporations that are our partners, that support the organization and allow us to do our programming, and then also allow us to be able to invest and inject capital into those companies." - Felecia Hatcher
- **On Holistic Approach:** "We have therapists on staff that support our entrepreneurs through a program called Evoke. So the entrepreneurs get group wellness and mental health support." - Felecia Hatcher

### Final Thoughts:
In this episode, Felecia Hatcher not only shares the foundation and vision behind Black Ambition but also provides actionable advice for anyone looking to make a mark in the entrepreneurial world. Her emphasis on holistic support and community-driven growth offers a refreshing and impactful perspective on how to cultivate sustainable success.

title: Breaking Barriers: How Felecia Hatcher and Pharrell Williams Support Black & Hispanic Entrepreneurs
description:
Welcome to this clip of EYL, where we dive deep into the inspiring stories and groundbreaking initiatives shaping the world of entrepreneurship. In this clip, our hosts Rashad Bilal and Troy Millings sit down with the phenomenal Felecia Hatcher, the dynamic leader behind Black Ambition, a revolutionary initiative founded by Pharrell Williams.

**What is Black Ambition?**
Felecia Hatcher kicks off the discussion by explaining what Black Ambition is all about. Launched four years ago by Pharrell Williams, Black Ambition aims to create uninterrupted opportunities for Black, Hispanic, and HBCU entrepreneurs. The initiative provides funding, community contacts, resources, and support, ensuring that these entrepreneurs can achieve their dreams without the constant interruptions and setbacks typically encountered.

**Inspiration from Lovecraft Country**
Felecia shares a compelling anecdote from her first conversation with Pharrell, inspired by a scene from the HBO show Lovecraft Country. The powerful question posed in the show, "Who were you uninterrupted?" becomes a central theme for Black Ambition. The goal is to help entrepreneurs envision and build a future where they can operate without obstacles, constantly moving forward with a green light at every intersection in their journey.

**Uninterrupted Pathways to Success**
The focus of Black Ambition is not only on helping entrepreneurs become better businesspeople but also on reducing the interruptions they face. By aligning all necessary resources and support, Black Ambition aims to provide a clear, unobstructed path to success, enabling entrepreneurs to thrive and scale their businesses efficiently.

**Meeting of the Minds**
Troy Millings inquires about how Felecia and Pharrell aligned their visions and came together. Felecia recounts her journey of co-founding the Center for Black Innovation and building Black Tech Week. Her extensive work in Miami's Black tech ecosystem eventually led Pharrell's chief of staff to invite her to lead Black Ambition. Despite a rocky initial meeting, Felecia's push-back and visionary ideas impressed Pharrell's team, leading to her current role.

**Goals and Achievements**
Rashad Bilal highlights the ambitious goal of raising over $95 million to support 100 entrepreneurs. Felecia elaborates on the structured process of achieving this goal through a prize competition. Each year, Black Ambition identifies 250 entrepreneurs, who then undergo a rigorous three-month mentorship program. From this cohort, around 35 companies receive significant investments. To date, Black Ambition has invested in 101 entrepreneurs, who have collectively raised over $95 million.

**Expert Insights and Advice**
Drawing from her extensive experience with companies like Nintendo, Sony, Target, Disney, and Google, Felecia offers invaluable advice to aspiring entrepreneurs. She emphasizes the importance of not being intimidated by large corporations, noting that agility and quick decision-making are the secret weapons of small businesses.

Join us for this enlightening conversation as we delve into the visionary journey of Felecia Hatcher and learn about the impactful work of Black Ambition. This episode is a must-watch for anyone interested in entrepreneurship, innovation, and creating a more inclusive and supportive ecosystem for underrepresented communities.

title: Launching and supporting Black-owned businesses | Mandy Bowman | TEDxDover
description:
We've read stats showing that Blacks have a buying power of $1.2 Trillion dollars and that Black women are starting businesses at a faster rate than any other group, but is this enough to change the economic inequalities that plague Black neighborhoods? Mandy Bowman discusses how it's time to focus on creating and supporting Black businesses to build long term/generational wealth.

Mandy Bowman is the Founder of Official Black Wall Street and the Social Media Manager at Essence Magazine. With a deep-rooted passion for all things social media, entrepreneurship, and Black culture, Mandy has worked tirelessly to empower and support Black entrepreneurs through her digital platform and Black business directory, Official Black Wall Street. When she isn't working to fuel Black businesses through the Official Black Wall Street platform, she is volunteering as a mentor to inner city students and creating social strategies.

This talk was given at a TEDx event using the TED conference format but independently organized by a local community. Learn more at http://ted.com/tedx
